intro: Cadaba somalensis, commonly known as the Somali mallow, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Somalia and Ethiopia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and large, showy flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, often reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are usually pink or purple, with five petals. Cadaba somalensis is adapted to dry climates and is often found in rocky or sandy soils.
